Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Optimizing Multibeam Data Acquisition Operations and Quality for the U.S. Academic Research Fleet
Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative effort proposes to establish technical resources and new communication mechanisms to develop and share common information, tools, and expertise regarding the operation and monitoring of multibeam sonars across the U.S. Academic Fleet. The strategy is to create a community of stakeholders including representatives from each operating institution, complemented by key outside experts from the user and technical/engineering communities that can assist in providing guidance on a broad array of multibeam issues to improve how these data are collected and assessed. In addition, the effort proposes to establish a Multibeam Advisory Committee (MAC) that will act as an overall coordinating body with the primary goal of supporting mapping operations onboard vessels in the U.S. academic research fleet and ensuring that high quality data are consistently acquired. They will also assemble small groups of individuals from the MAC and community of stakeholders into technical teams, each of which is tasked with specific components of multibeam system performance evaluation.

Broader Impacts
The principal impact of the present proposal is under criterion two, providing infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The support of maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers. All users (or the appropriate funding agencies) share support for basic pooled services on the vessel equally, with NSF paying a share of the support costs based on fractional usage of the vessel during the year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multibeam sonars are complex mapping systems that have become standard instruments across many ships in the U.S. Academic Research Fleet.  Data produced by these systems are used to create maps of ocean depth (bathymetry) and seafloor characteristics that are essential for a wide range of oceanographic studies.  While these sonars are common, their complexity requires careful installation, integration, and maintenance in order to consistently produce high-quality data.  

This project focused on developing a new fleet-wide approach for supporting multibeam sonar operations by coordinating sonar calibration efforts, performing consistent and routine assessment of system performance, and developing tools and protocols for consistent data acquisition practices. Our strategy was to gain efficiencies of scale by working with the community of stakeholders, including scientists, sonar specialists and shipboard technical personnel, to gather existing information, develop new resources and establish new communication mechanisms for sharing resources and information.

This collaborative project established 3 technical teams of experts to focus on complementary aspects of multibeam system calibration, operation and performance assessment. Members of these technical teams worked closely with vessel operators and visited ships periodically to review system performance, install software tools and provide training to seagoing technicians.  Shore-based technical team activities included liaising with the science community, periodic fleet-wide review of multibeam data quality and technical assistance when system performance and/or data quality concerns arose. These technical teams facilitated the critical flow of information necessary to develop resources and improve consistency with respect to multibeam sonar operations across the fleet.

All resources generated by this effort, including more than 25 technical reports, 10 best practice guideline documents and resources, and several software tools, are publicly available at http://mac.unols.org.
